qas.question: What text is the foundation of the study of the history of science?
Who wrote a more professional version of History of the Inductive Sciences?
What was the history of science during the 20th century?

answers.text: the history of great men and great ideas

qas.question: How could Sarton's ideas be described?
Who studied the history of science?

context: As an academic field, history of science began with the publication of William Whewell's <a0_0>History of the Inductive Sciences<a0_0/> (first published in 1837). A more formal study of the history of science as an independent discipline was launched by <a1_0>George Sarton's<a1_0/> publications, Introduction to the History of Science (1927) and the Isis journal (founded in 1912). Sarton exemplified the early 20th-century view of the history of science as <a2_0>the history of great men and great ideas<a2_0/>. He shared with many of his contemporaries a <a3_0>Whiggish<a3_0/> belief in history as a record of the advances and delays in the march of progress. The history of science was not a recognized subfield of American history in this period, and most of the work was carried out by <a4_0>interested scientists and physicians<a4_0/> rather than professional historians. With the work of I. Bernard Cohen at Harvard, the history of science became an established subdiscipline of history after 1945.
